name: phosphoric acid production, dihydrate process | phosphoric acid, fertiliser grade, without water, in 70% solution state | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/10043/documentation

The process describes the production of phosphoric acid from phosphate rock with the dyhydrate process in Florida. As products of the multi output process fertiliser grade phosphoric acid (impure with 51% P2O5) and dilute fluosilic acid (22% in H2O) was considered.

Raw materials, processing chemicals and processing energy, direct emissions to air from process, emissions to air and water from phosphogypsum storage, emission of radioactive substances from gypsum to air and water, land use for phosphogypsum storage and processing ponds, transport of raw materials to the plant, estimation for process infrastructure . The process includes data on emissions and land use from phosphogypsum storage.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2012:Manufacture of fertilizers and nitrogen compounds

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data for amount of phosphoric acid production from statisitcs of IFA (International Fertiliser Agency). Data on phosphoric acid process from various studies made in Florida and from different literature sources concerning also other locations other than U.S. Data for processes used in Florida extrapolated for the whole United States. Only production from wet rock considered as in the mayority of the sites in Florida used. Data for production of fluosilic acid from one european study (EFMA). This data was was used for the whole U.S. production.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Data refers to wet-phosphoric acid production from phosphate rock by the dihydrate process. Technology with cooling ponds and gypsum stacks as used in Florida was applied.  Balanced water management assumed.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Production assessed with mixed data from the phosphoric acid production in Florida. Therefore it is difficult to give a precise nuber for the representativity of the data. It was assumed that the data cover about 30-50% of the U.S. production. The total amount of fluosilic acid produced is not known. The production was assessed with weak data from one source. Therefore no representativity of the data can be given for fluosilic acid production.

exchanges.description:
It is assumed that the process is 96% efficient in terms of the phosphate rock input. Phosphate rock has a P2O5 equal to 32% and phosphoric acid has a P2O5 content of 51%. 
References:  Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA D端bendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, D端bendorf, CH, from www.ecoinvent.org.

It is assumed that 2.75 kg of sulfuric acid are used per kg of P2O5 in the phosphoric acid, which has a P2O5 content of 51%.
References:  Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA D端bendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, D端bendorf, CH, from www.ecoinvent.org.

exchanges.description: Estimation based on 1 Source, calculated

Calculated based on literature, (Vionnet, S., Quantis Water Database - Technical Report, 2012). It includes the process: grinding, processing, filtration, concentration, etc. The process ends when finished phosphoric acid leaves the plant. It is assumed that there is no process water use (the source of information assumes the same).
